facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2025 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2025 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 18th October 1967 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in C.C.C. Appeal No. 46 of 1963

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the 18th October,1967 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in C. C. C. Appeal No. 46 of 1963.

facts.text: Land acquisition proceedings under Hyderabad Land Acquisition Act IX of 1309 Fasli

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by certificate, arises out of land acquisition proceedings under the Hyderabad Land Acquisition Act  Hyderabad Act IX of 1309 Fasli   hereinafter called the Act, for short  which substantially resembles the provisions of the Central Land Acquisition Act.

facts.text: Government of Andhra Pradesh acquired large open area with some buildings by Notification dated January 3, 1957 for Income-tax and Central Excise Offices at Hyderabad

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Andhra Pradesh acquired a large open area with some buildings thereon by Notification, dated January 3, 1957 with a view to construct Income-tax and Central Excise Offices at Hyderabad.

facts.text: Acquired land had a building with plinth area of 3,300 sq. yds.

anchor.surface_text: The land, vast in extent, had a building with a plinth area of 3,300 sq. yds.

facts.text: Acquired plot situated in an important area in Hyderabad City

anchor.surface_text: The area in which the acquired plot is situate is perhaps an important one in the City.

facts.text: Collector awarded Rs. 41,674 for buildings

anchor.surface_text: After getting expert valuation made of the buildings by the Central Public Works Department engineers, the Collector awarded a sum of Rs. 41,674/- for the buildings,

facts.text: Collector awarded Rs. 1,440 for standing trees

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 41,674/- for the buildings, Rs. 1,440/- for the standing trees

facts.text: Collector awarded Rs. 30,630 for belt of land 50 ft. deep at Rs. 15 per square yard

anchor.surface_text: and a sum of Rs. 30,630/for a belt of land 50 ft. deep at Rs. 15/- per square yard

facts.text: Collector awarded Rs. 99,435 for remaining area of 13,258 sq. yds.

anchor.surface_text: and Rs. 99,435/- for the remaining area of 13,258 sq. yds.

facts.text: Total compensation by Collector with solatium Rs. 1,99,155.85

anchor.surface_text: The, total figure together with statutory solarium granted by the Collector was Rs. 1,99,155.85.

facts.text: City Civil Court enhanced compensation to Rs. 3,31,092

anchor.surface_text: when the case came before the City Civil Court on a reference, there was an enhancement of compensation. Although the learned Additional Chief Judge held that the area was a little less than had been determined by the Collector, the market value of the building was increased nearly four fold on the basis of a multiple of 25 times the rent fetched. On the other items also some changes were made and, consequently, the total amount was raised to Rs. 3,31,092/-

facts.text: City Civil Court held area slightly less than determined by Collector

anchor.surface_text: Although the learned Additional Chief Judge held that the area was a little less than had been determined by the Collector,

facts.text: High Court altered multiple from 25 to 27 for building compensation

anchor.surface_text: Some measure of good fortune attended the appeal since the High Court altered the multiple from 25 to 27 in fixing the compensation for the building.

facts.text: High Court restored the area acquired as determined by Collector

anchor.surface_text: Otherwise, it substantially affirmed the findings of the trial Court, except that to the advantage of the appellant it restored the area acquired.

facts.text: High Court awarded total compensation of Rs. 3,52,326.65 to appellant

anchor.surface_text: The net result was the appellant obtained a total sum of Rs. 3,52,326.65 as compensation.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court but appeal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appellant arrived in the High Court asking for more  and the State also appears to have appealed, but its appeal was dismissed

facts.text: High Court awarded Rs. 20 per sq yd for 2042 sq yds 50 ft wide belt and Rs. 10 per sq yd for rest

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the physical features of the property, its situation in an important locality and the price paid for a small extent of level ground acquired for the Telephone Exchange which is at a distance of about half a mile from the property acquired, we hold that the compensation awarded by the Court below at Rs. 20/- per square yard for the 2042 square yards constituting the 50 wide belt and at Rs. 10/- per square yard for the rest is fair and reasonable.

facts.text: Terrain uneven with difference in levels of 27 feet and boulders

anchor.surface_text: The terrain, in this case, appears to have been uneven with difference in levels to the extent of 27 feet and boulders here and there making building operations expensive in the initial preparation of the site.

facts.text: Buildings acquired over 30 years old

anchor.surface_text: We must also remember that the Court below has been indulgent enough to adopt a multiple of 27 despite the fact that the buildings acquired are over 30 years old.

facts.text: Appellant sought higher multiple of 33-1/2 times for capitalisation

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged before us that the multiple of 27 for purposes of capitalisation, adopted by the High Court, was inadequate and that the owner was entitled to capitalisation by multiplication 33-1/2 times.

facts.text: No evidence placed on record for big potential value of land

anchor.surface_text: However, the High Court noted that no evidence whatever was placed on record in substantiation of any big potential value based on the unique features of the land.

facts.text: Belting method adopted at instance of appellant before Collector

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the objection to divide the plot for purposes of differential valuation has not been taken at the proper level. On the contrary, it has been adopted originally at the instance of the appellant himself, before the Collector

facts.text: Interest on Government Securities around mid 1957 ranged between 3% and 4%

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A-7, the notification produced by the appellant, itself shows that around the middle of 1957 the rate of interest allowed on Government Securities at the relevant time ranged between 31 and 4.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal

anchor.surface_text: and his appeal, virtually against concurrent findings of fact, therefore deserves to be, and is hereby, dismissed with costs.

This appeal, by certificate, arises out of land acquisition proceedings under the Hyderabad Land Acquisition Act  Hyderabad Act IX of 1309 Fasli   hereinafter called the Act, for short  which substantially resembles the provisions of the Central Land Acquisition Act.

issues.text: Whether there is any substantial question of law of general importance in counsel's submissions or the points outlined in the memorandum of appeal which merits the consideration of this Court?

anchor.surface_text: We mention this because we are unable to discern any substantial question of law of general importance in counsels submissions or the points outlined in the memorandum of appeal which merits the consideration of this Court. Merely because the claim is large the judgment need not be long and,

issues.text: Whether the courts below failed to consider the precious potential value of the acquired land due to Hyderabad's development?

anchor.surface_text: The burden of the song has been that Hyderabad has, for his- torical reasons, become a great city and that the land acquired has precious potential value which has not entered the judicial computation at the lesser levels.  By way of aside one, may say that society economic development of a City- may enhance the value of space without any the littlest contribution by its owner and it is, in one sense, unfair that society should pay to an individual a higher price not because he has-earned it but because of other developmental factors.

issues.text: Whether the methodology of breaking up the totality into buildings and lands separately and sub-dividing the land into two portions on the principle of belting was wrong?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel has also urged that the land and the building taken together had a personality of its own and therefore a special value, missed by the courts below, should be ascribed and the methodology of breaking up the totality into buildings and lands separately and sub- dividing the land into two portions on the principle of. belting was all wrong. It was also urged before us that the multiple of 27 for purposes of capitalisation, adopted by the High Court, was inadequate and that the owner was en- titled to capitalisation by multiplication 33-1/2 times.

issues.text: Whether the multiple of 27 adopted by the High Court for capitalisation of rent was inadequate and the owner was entitled to 33-1/2 times?

anchor.surface_text: We find that the High Court has carefully considered all available points, indeed stretching them in favour of the appellant, where that was warranted by the facts... The next question is whether the multiple adopted for capitalisation has been prejudicially low, Exhibit A-7, the notification produced by the appellant, itself shows that around the middle of 1957 the rate of interest allowed on Government Securities at the relevant time ranged between 31 and 4.

issues.text: Whether the concurrent findings of fact below on compensation ought to be disturbed?

anchor.surface_text: We are thus satisfied that there is no law, no fact, which comes to the rescue of the appellant and his appeal, virtually against concurrent findings of fact, therefore deserves to be, and is hereby, dismissed with costs.
